title: Basic Concepts of Financial Analysis
headline: Improve your accounting skills by learning finance-related aspects and concepts with this free online course.
description: Understand the basic concepts of finance and accounting. Become familiar with the world of banking and commerce in detail. This free online course is an excellent opportunity to step up your accounting knowledge and raise your financial skills. It will cement your understanding of the fundamental concepts of finance and commerce and prepare you to analyze financial statements and matters independently. Enroll today!
courseDescription:
Are you a commerce student studying for exams or trying to find a job? Are you a banking professional who wants to raise your skills or refresh your knowledge of financial fundamentals or somebody who finds it a challenge to understand financial matters and concepts? This course will improve your skills by teaching you economic fundamentals and concepts. We will also prepare you to analyze and work out financial statements unassisted.

Blended with case studies, this course on financial analysis is a combination of conceptual and practical ideas. You gain in-depth financial knowledge with detailed analysis and interpretations of accounting concepts like financial statements and financial ratio calculations. For ease of learning, we have divided the course into three modules with several financial and accounting topics. These topics include financial statements, balance sheet concepts, income statements, operating cycles, ratio analysis and interpretation and the ‘break-even’ concept. Explanations of these concepts are downloadable from the ‘Resources’ section as resource guides to help you gain and retain valuable knowledge.

So if you are preparing for competitive exams, are a student of commerce, a small investor or have a passion for the subject matter, this financial analysis course might be a perfect fit. Join this free online course, enroll and quickly learn the fundamentals of finance-related aspects to raise your mastery and knowledge to advance your career.

Start Course Now

• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define a financial statement.
    • Describe different types of financial statements.
    • Explain balance sheet structure along with its elements and liabilities.
    • Define the concept of reserve and surplus with examples.
    • Explain fixed assets and related concepts like depreciation, gross block, and netblock in detail.
    • Describe in detail other assets such as intangible, current, and investments.

  • Balance Sheet Structure & Concepts

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • Financial statements are the reports that provide detailed information about the financial position of the business, its operational performance, and its cash flow in the accounting period. It is prepared at the end of the accounting period.
    • There are three types of financial statements, the balance sheets, the income statements or profit or loss statements, and the cash flow statements.
    • The balance sheet tells us about the fund position in the business ie the source of funds for business. It is drawn on the last day of the accounting period and consists of liabilities and Assets.
    • Liabilities refer to what is owed by the business ie the sources of funds like the owner's capital, reserves and surplus, and outside liabilities. Liabilities are divided into two parts equity and outside borrowings.
    • Equity is the owner's capital invested in the business. Outside borrowings are money borrowed from outside to be returned in the due course.
    • Assets refer to what is owned by the business or applications of the fund like investments in land and buildings. Assets can be divided into four main groups, fixed assets, intangible assets, investments, and short-term or current assets.
    • Fixed assets or tangible assets refer to physical assets like land, buildings, machinery. Intangible assets are the non-physical assets one can not touch or feel. Investments are the assets that do not generate any operative income but increase efficiency in the business. Short-term assets or current assets are those assets that convert them into cash or cash equivalent into a short period usually within 12 months.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Discuss in detail what an income statement is.
    • Explain how to analyze and interpret the income statement.
    • Describe the concept of working capital and its operating cycle.
    • Define what financial ratios are.
    • Explain how to work out the liquidity ratio within a balance sheet.
    • Describe all the different types of financial Ratios and their application in detail.
    • Describe how to summarize all the ratios and carry out an interpretation of a firm's performance.

  • Introduction to Ratios

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • An income statement is an important financial statement that provides the income stream of the business during the year and also informs us whether the business has earned profits or incurred losses.
    • An income statement is made up of three parts, income, expenses, and profit or losses.
    • An operating cycle can be a gross operating cycle or net operating cycle.
    • The gross operating cycle is also called the cash to cash cycle. It is the time taken from the purchase of raw material in cash to the realization of receivables in cash.
    • The net operating cycle is the period we get by deducting the time provided by the creditors to pay from the gross operating cycle.
    • Ratios are a relationship between two variables one on the numerator and the other on the denominator, created in a logical way to make a meaningful decision.
    • Financial ratios can be broadly classified under four categories. Liquidity, solvency, turnover, and profitability ratios.Liquidity ratios help analyzes the liquidity position of the business by matching assets and liabilities.
    • Solvency ratios analyze the ability of firms to meet their long-time debts and financial obligations.
    • Turnover ratios study the capacity of the firms to manage their working capital.
    • Profitability ratios are most important for every stakeholder. It helps understand how the organization is working to improve the profitability and also the wealth of owners and shareholders.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define Debt service coverage ratio or DSCR.
    • Explain the DSCR concept with a case study for term loans.
    • Discuss in detail the Security coverage ratio along with the standard benchmark ratio in banks.
    • Explain the types of Security coverage ratios.
    • Describe Break-Even Analysis along with all the aspects in detail.
    • Explain the Break-Even Analysis concept with a case study.

  • Break Even Analysis

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • The debt service coverage ratio or DSCR is most important for the appraisal of a term loan.
    • Debt service coverage ratio or DSCR is a tool to appraise the overall payment capacity of the borrower to meet his debt obligations.
    • There are two types of DSCR, Gross DSCR, and Net DSCR.
    • Gross DSCR measures the ability of the firm to repay the total debt obligation ie the principal installment and the interest repayment.Net DSCR measures the ability of the business to repay only the principal installment.
    • Security coverage ratios are of two types, asset coverage ratio, and collateral coverage ratio.
    • The asset coverage ratio measures the total of primary security and the collateral security to loan exposure. The collateral coverage ratio only measures only the value of collateral security to the loan exposure.
    • Break-Even Analysis is also called CVP analysis ie cost volume and profit analysis.
    • Break-Even Analysis is a study of the interrelationship of the cost of the product, its volume of sales, and its resultant profits.
    • Break-Even of a firm is calculated as fixed cost/contribution.
